Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Research and Education in Theoretical Biophysics: Physical Principles Governing Biochemical Signaling Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this CAREER award aims at understanding the principles governing the design of biochemical signaling networks. The cell's crucial functions, growth, differentiation and the generation of specialized properties, are carried out by networks of biochemical reactions. The research will examine the theoretical limits set by fundamental physics, such as thermal fluctuations leading to chemical kinetic rate fluctuations and diffusive noise, on the accuracy of biochemical signaling. The idea of performance at the limits set by physical laws will be explored to understand biochemical signaling processing by the cell, from the level of a single network element, such as a biochemical switch, to the organization of the signaling network governing precise morphogen gradient detection in early embryonic development. Design principles ensuring robustness to inherent sources of noise will be investigated for various biochemical signaling networks, such as the bacterial chemotaxis signal transduction network and phototransduction in vertebrate retinal cells. Optimality in biochemical signal processing will be explored in the context of the well-characterized bacterial signal transduction network from information theoretic considerations. Organizing principles such as performance at physical limits will be used to constrain unknown and partially known molecular mechanisms.

Synergistic activities that fall under the long-term scope of this CAREER activity involve ongoing collaborations with biologists on problems inspired directly by experiments. These include understanding optimal strategies in nutrient uptake by Caulobacter crescentus and the role of motility and chemotaxis in initial stages of biofilm formation. The educational component builds on the interdisciplinary nature of the research platform and provides seed initiatives for further developing the nascent graduate biophysics program in the Physics department at Indiana University, Bloomington, and interfacing it with the undergraduate curriculum. It encompasses the development of courses at three levels, for non-scientists, undergraduate science majors as well as advanced graduate students. The education and outreach efforts are strongly aimed at the notion that scientists and non-scientists alike are confronted by issues and problems that require multidisciplinary training and thinking.

Funding for this award is provided by the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences and by the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacteria constitute the so-called “hydrogen atom” of cell biology, where their single cell and collective behaviors present powerful model systems for unraveling biological organization in general.  The rate of growth and division and the ability to spread to new, potentially better environments are the major determinants of the fitness of bacterial populations in natural habitats, with chemosensing, motility and adhesion playing important roles in their directed motion and surface colonization.  The research thrusts of this award focused on theoretical/computational studies of physical principles underlying biochemical signaling networks and the mechanisms they govern:  (1) regulation of bacterial motility and adhesion as mechanisms crucial for surface colonization, leading to biofilm formation and possibly virulence, (2) physical limits and optimality in bacterial sensing and response, and (3) evolution of higher order protein structure driven by cooperativity in multimers.  These thrusts involved collaboration with experimental groups, with attention to potential biomimetic applications such as development of strong glues derived from bacterial adhesins and efficient, synthetic micropropulsion based on bacterial strategies:

(i)            With experimental collaborators, we identified novel spontaneous mutations in the motility apparatus of the plant pathogen Agrobacterium tumefaciens gutted of chemotaxis network proteins.  These mutations led to randomly occurring reorientations, or tumbles, in the otherwise the straight-swimming phenotype of chemotaxis-deficient cells, rescuing the nonexpanding colonies of the parent strain in motility agar.  We developed a theoretical description of bacterial run-and-tumble diffusion in porous media, such as a biofilm matrix, soil or tissue, which elucidates how modifications of the motility apparatus resulting in a nonzero tumbling frequency allows for unjamming of cells at internal boundaries, leading to net migration. 

(ii)          The marine bacterium Caulobacter crescentus has been shown to adhere to a variety of surfaces using a microscopic holdfast anchor, characterized as nature’s strongest glue. With experimental collaborators, through analysis of dynamic force microscopy measurements of the holdfast rupture forces, we found that the strength of adhesion is strongly time dependent, suggesting a curing process.  A model accounting for kinetics of adhesion-surface interaction, coupled to diffusion of adhesin in the holdfast bulk captures the experimental time dependence.

(iii)         Biochemical signaling is the most fundamental stage of information processing in living systems. We employed a detailed, stochastic model of the E. coli chemotaxis network – a canonical example of sensory transduction at the single cell level – to establish its systems-level properties.  We identified the dominant network filters, given by time averaging and differentiating operations.  We demonstrated adaptation of the input-output (IO) response to the statistics of the input: IO relations for input stimuli with the same coefficient of variation collapse onto a universal function. We showed that due to this rescaling, the mutual information between the input and output is approximately constant for signals with the same coefficient of variation.

(iv)         The performance of biological systems near physical limits has been demonstrated in a variety of biological systems and scales.  At the level of biochemical signaling, cooperative interactions in the binding of multiple signaling molecules is a common mechanism for enhancing sensitivity. Extending previous work on the physical limits of chemoreception, we showed that cooperativity makes reaching the limit set by the random arrival of diffusing signaling molecules at receptors easier, but cannot reduce the limit itself.  Also in the context of chemosensing, we developed a numerical method for elucidating the design principles underlying noisy or near-perfect adaptation (in E. coli chemotaxis), necessary for continued sensitive response to time-varying stimuli.

(v)          Many proteins assemble into multimeric structures. Protein-protein interactions require productive encounters among subunits, which depend on cellular protein abundance, in turn determined by rates of production/decay of mRNA and protein molecules, as well as cell growth and division. We developed a stochastic model for predicting the multimeric state of a protein as a function of these processes and the free energy of binding. We demonstrated favorable agreement between the model prediction and a wide class of proteins using E. coli proteome data. We investigated cooperative activity of multimers as a possible selective force driving multimerization, demonstrating increased benefit for given cost of protein production that can be tied to fitness.

Educational and outreach components of the award built on the interdisciplinary nature of the research platform, contributing to the development of the graduate biophysics program within the Physics department at Indiana University by introducing new, graduate biophysics courses.  These courses have also served students from other degree programs, including biology, chemistry, biochemistry, geology and optometry. The strong focus of the PI’s research platform on collaboration with experimental groups led to joint training of postdocs and graduate students by faculty in physics, chemistry and biology.  The PI was active in community science outreach in departmental and elementary school venues. She has served as faculty fellow to the newly developed Women in Science, Technology, Informatics and Math living-learning community at IU, which she helped establish.
